llm.feedback: Your draft is essentially a blank canvas – it lacks any of the core elements that a world‑class scenario analysis must contain. To bring it up to the required standard, first map a 3–6 month horizon with a clear causal chain: start with macro drivers (e.g., U.S. GDP growth, interest‑rate trajectory, supply‑chain bottlenecks), then link them to sector‑specific catalysts (e.g., UAS job growth, OEM laptop‑to‑office shift, Toyota RAV4 electrification rollout). For each link, quantify the impact (e.g., a 0.5 % GDP rise → +$2 bn in UAS revenue; a 10 % shift to hybrid RAV4s → +$1.5 bn in Toyota sales). Build a scenario map that lists triggers (e.g., tariff announcement, new FDA approval) and invalidations (e.g., supply‑chain collapse, consumer shift to cloud‑based work). Integrate flows (e.g., capital outlays, labor‑cost changes) and valuation (DCF ranges, EV/EBITDA multiples). Use the source IDs (FOM34PUWA, U0I2AFHOV, WISLWAJ15, GUJQZY4UO, H8880U45S) to cite specific numbers: 97 % UAS job rise (FOM34PUWA), Abbott’s 53‑year dividend streak (WISLWAJ15), Toyota’s 111,526 hybrid RAV4s sold (H8880U45S). Ensure every critical source is referenced, reconcile any conflicting data (e.g., UAS revenue vs. job numbers), and avoid generic statements. Finally, end with a base case, 1–2 alternative scenarios, risk flags, watch‑list signals, and a confidence rating. This structured, data‑driven approach will transform the draft into a rigorous, actionable analysis.
